Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Diversity and Symbiosis: Examining the Taxonomic, Genetic, and Functional Diversity of Amphibian Skin Microbiota
Award.AbstractNarration:
In adult humans, symbiotic microbes outnumber human cells ten to one. The composition of these microbial communities can influence whether individuals are lean or obese and the likelihood that pathogens are able to successfully establish themselves in the body. Amphibians also possess a diverse symbiotic microbiota, and these bacterial symbionts may limit infection by pathogens, such as the fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) that has decimated many natural amphibian populations. This research will examine links between three critical diversity components of the symbiotic microbial communities that reside on amphibian skin: taxonomic diversity (number and relative abundance of species), genetic diversity (which genes are turned on), and functional diversity (disease resistance). Using focused field surveys and manipulative experiments, three objectives will be addressed: (1) establish the range of taxonomic, genetic, and functional diversity within the microbial community on five species of host amphibians in Panama, (2) examine how the presence of a pathogen (Bd) impacts diversity components, and (3) examine the relationship between microbial diversity and resistance to disease. As all animals host symbiotic microbes, these results will have broad applicability to other systems, including humans. In addition, new statistical methods for these complex datasets will be developed, which will rapidly expand the ability to integrate these diversity components in a wide array of systems.

Undergraduate students will be trained in research. In addition, in Panama, a partnership with the Panama Amphibian Rescue and Conservation Project (PARC) will be established. A PARC intern will be supported to work with school groups to stress the importance of conservation, beneficial microbes and biodiversity. The partnership with PARC will extend to working with them on novel probiotic solutions, based on antifungal skin bacteria, that will allow successful reintroductions of threatened frogs, thereby helping to restore biodiversity to the Neotropics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The microbiomes of animals are complex communities of microbes that live on and in animal hosts.  Recent research suggests many of these microbes play critical roles in many facets of host development, physiology and overall health.  This project investigated the amphibian skin microbiome, with the ultimate goal of understanding how these complex communities might function in host immune defense against a potentially lethal fungus that can infect amphibian skin. Many of the underlying mechanisms at work in this system may be paralleled in other animal-microbe systems.  We found that the amphibian skin microbiome is composed of microbes that are relatively rare in the environment, and that each host species and even most populations tend to have unique skin communities that include both bacteria and fungi. The skin microbiome is not just composed of the most common environmental microbes that are picked up by amphibians. This suggests that there is likely some host selection for specific microbes occurring, although this is impacted by the available source pool of microbes in the environment.

In several experimental studies, we found evidence that the microbial community present on the skin at the time of exposure to the fungal pathogen may play a role in determining the outcome of exposure.  However, it also seems that many different bacterial species provide the same function for their host, in this case, by producing antifungal compounds that can alter fungal infection dynamics.  Therefore, there may be functional redundancy in these complex microbial communities, with many different communities proving to be effective for a host in preventing fungal infection. We also found that most dominant members of the amphibian skin microbiome can be effectively cultured and grown in the laboratory, which is important for the potential development of probiotic bacteria-based approaches to amphibian conservation in regions where the pathogenic fungus is now present. Working with isolates is going to be critical for truly understanding the interactions and the functions of these complex microbial communities across all systems, as to use bacteria effectively in any application, they must be grown in the lab.  As we worked with these data, the statisticians on the project also developed several new statistical approaches to analyze these large, complex datasets, which is an important contribution; these new methods can be applied in many different fields of science that face challenges from the increasing size and scope of datasets.  

As part of the broader impacts of this research, we tested a large set of bacterial isolates from amphibian skin for their antifungal properties.  This work moved us toward a probiotic solution to preventing fungal infection, and in combination with our extensive outreach efforts done in collaboration with the Smithsonian Institute, will have meaningful long-lasting impacts on conservation of amphibians and their habitats. In addition, our isolate collection likely includes bacteria that are new to science, and could prove to be an important future source of new bacterial compounds. Also as part of this award, 15 individuals were mentored in scientific research.  Training students and young scientists to think and work in an interdisciplinary environment provides for a talented, productive and creative work force that drives innovation and economic growth.
